question.text: Some people think individuals should take responsibility for protecting the environment, while others believe governments should be responsible. Discuss both views and give your opinion.

guidancePanel.title: Writing Tips
tips: Follow your plan from Section 4 - don't change structure midway
Use topic sentences to start each body paragraph
Include linking words (However, Furthermore, For instance)
Avoid contractions (don't → do not, can't → cannot)
Leave 5 minutes at the end to check for errors

sections.title: Check Your Essay
sections.description: Use this checklist to review your work

items.label: Introduction clearly paraphrases the question (not copied)
tips: Use synonyms: individuals → citizens, protecting → conservation, responsibility → accountability

items.label: Body paragraph 1 has clear topic sentence about individual responsibility
tips: Topic sentence = first sentence stating main idea

items.label: Body paragraph 2 discusses government responsibility
tips: Use transition: However, On the other hand, Conversely

items.label: Conclusion summarizes both views + states opinion clearly
tips: Your opinion must be clear - who should be primarily responsible?

items.label: Both views are discussed with equal detail
tips: Count sentences - each view should have similar length

items.label: Personal opinion is clearly stated
tips: Use: In my view, I believe that, From my perspective

items.label: Specific examples are provided for each view
tips: Real examples like specific countries or policies are strongest

items.label: All parts of the question are fully addressed
No repeated words - synonyms used throughout
Topic vocabulary from Section 2 is used correctly
Complex sentences are used (not all simple sentences)
tips: Use: who, which, that, although, while, because

items.label: Verb tenses are consistent and correct

sections.title: Band 8 Model Answer
sections.description: Compare your essay with this high-band example

essay.fullEssay:
The question of who bears primary accountability for environmental protection divides opinion between those advocating citizen action and those emphasizing state intervention. While individual efforts are valuable, I believe governments must take the leading role in environmental conservation due to their unique capacity for systemic change.

On the one hand, personal lifestyle choices collectively create significant environmental impact. When millions of people make conscious decisions to reduce consumption, recycle waste, and choose sustainable transportation, the cumulative effect substantially decreases pollution and resource depletion. For instance, the growing popularity of reusable shopping bags and water bottles has measurably reduced plastic waste in many communities. Furthermore, individual actions raise environmental awareness and inspire others to adopt eco-friendly habits, creating grassroots momentum for broader societal change. Citizens also wield considerable power through their purchasing decisions, potentially influencing companies to adopt more sustainable practices.

However, governments possess the authority and resources necessary to implement large-scale environmental policies that individual actions cannot achieve. Only state institutions can regulate industrial emissions, enforce environmental standards, and invest in renewable energy infrastructure at the scale required to address climate change effectively. The European Union's strict emission regulations, for example, have achieved pollution reductions far beyond what voluntary individual efforts could accomplish. Moreover, governments can negotiate international agreements like the Paris Accord, coordinating global responses to environmental challenges that transcend national borders. Systematic environmental problems fundamentally require governmental solutions backed by legal enforcement and substantial financial investment.

In conclusion, while individual conservation efforts contribute meaningfully to environmental protection, governmental policies deliver the systematic impact necessary for significant progress. Therefore, states must lead environmental initiatives while simultaneously encouraging responsible citizenship.

strengths: Clear position with well-reasoned opinion favoring government
Both views discussed equally with specific examples
Strong topic sentences in each paragraph
Wide range of vocabulary (accountability, cumulative, transcend)
